title: reference request - Maximal order of $x^n-d$ and its dependence on $d$
body: It's well known that the structure of the maximal order of $\mathbb{Q}[\sqrt{d}]$ depends on $d$ modulo $4$ : (assuming $d$ is squarefree), the maximal order is $\mathbb{Z}\left[\frac{1+\sqrt{d}}{2}\right]$ if $d \equiv 1 \mod{4}$ and $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{d}]$ otherwise. The structure of the biquadratic extension $\mathbb{Q}[\sqrt{d},\sqrt{e}]$ has a similar but more complicated description. Now let's consider $K=\mathbb{Q}[\sqrt[n]{d}]$ . For simplicity, let's consider only $d$ prime. Based on some SAGE computation, it seems that there is a degree $n$ extension $M$ of $\mathbb{Q}[\mu_{n^2}]$ such that $\mathcal{O}_K$ contains more than just $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt[n]{d}]$ iff $d$ splits in $M$ . (Note that if $n$ is prime, then $M$ is unique.) For $n=2$ , one sees that $M=\mathbb{Q}[i]$ . Is this known? It doesn't seem too hard to prove that if $d$ is split, then there are more algebraic integers in $K$ . But does this appear anywhere? reference-request algebraic-number-theory class-field-theory Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 22, 2020 at 0:59 David Corwin 16k 11 11 gold badges 89 89 silver badges 128 128 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 1 2 $\begingroup$ You are asking when the ring of integers of $\mathbf Q(\sqrt[n]{d})$ is $\mathbf Z[\sqrt[n]{d}]$. Presumably you intend for $x^n - d$ to be irreducible (before you take $d$ prime for simplicity). See the theorems in kconrad.math.uconn.edu/blurbs/gradnumthy/integersradical.pdf . You might also be interested in arxiv.org/abs/1909.07184 , although it is about a setting over a base ring larger than $\mathbf Z$. $\endgroup$ KConrad –  KConrad 2020-07-22 02:46:51 +00:00 Commented Jul 22, 2020 at 2:46 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
